item.title: Liz Truss Resigns After 6 Chaotic Weeks, Igniting New Leadership Fight
item.description: The beleaguered British prime minister relinquished her office after just 44 days of political and economic tumult, the shortest tenure in British history.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss announcing her resignation on Thursday.

item.title: Liberated Ukrainians Share Tales of Russian Occupation
item.description: With Russian soldiers pushed out of parts of the Kharkiv region, Ukrainian investigators have been overwhelmed with accounts of detentions, torture and missing relatives, as well as collaboration and property theft.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Avdeev, 60, looked on as a rescue worker worked to exhume the body of his son Serhii Avdeev, who was abducted and killed by Russian forces last month, in Borova.

item.title: How Taiwan’s Ambitious Diplomacy Aims to Keep the Island Safe From China
item.description: Even as China’s threats on reunification grow more pointed, most recently at the Communist Party congress, Taiwan is working creatively to bolster its alliances.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese flags at Taiwan’s National Day celebrations in Taoyuan, Taiwan, this month.

item.title: Berlusconi, Caught on Tape Gushing Over Putin, Heightens Anxiety About Italy
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian leader and linchpin of the incoming right-wing government, blames Ukraine’s president for pushing President Vladimir V. Putin to invade.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The billionaire media mogul Silvio Berlusconi at a rally for his right-wing alliance last month in Rome.

item.title: A Shrinking Town at the Center of France’s Culture Wars
item.description: A plan to revitalize the town of Callac by bringing in skilled immigrants has divided it and made it an emblem of a nation’s anxiety over its identity and decline.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ibrahim Zakaria Youssouf, originally from Sudan, with his wife, Mariam Hissein Abderamam, outside their home in Callac, France, where they have been living for two years.

item.title: Mystery Surrounds Deadly Attack at a Notorious Myanmar Prison
item.description: A little-known group has claimed responsibility for two explosions, yet it remains unclear how the bombs got in, and how much of the carnage was a result of subsequent gunfire.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The main gate to Insein Prison in Yangon earlier this month. Explosions and shooting at a building where prisoners’ family members deliver packages killed eight people on Wednesday and injured 18.

item.title: Truss Defied the Markets, and They Ruthlessly Sealed Her Fate
item.description: World leaders buffeted by economic challenges are watching the turmoil in Britain with anything but relish, hoping that Liz Truss’s woes won’t be a harbinger for other countries.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene outside the Bank of England in central London. The market’s swift, withering verdict on Prime Minister Liz Truss’s tax-cutting agenda shattered her credibility.

item.title: Liz Truss Is Eligible for an Allowance of $129,000 a Year for Life
item.description: The departing British leader would be the sixth prime minister to receive the reimbursement for her expenses after leaving office.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss is eligible for the Public Duty Costs Allowance, a reimbursement of expenses incurred after she leaves office.

item.title: Liz Truss’s Quick Resignation Spurs Anger and Bewilderment Among Britons
item.description: Prime Minister Liz Truss’s resignation, yet another episode of political instability, only added to concerns over galloping inflation and a looming economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Alex Ingram for The New York Times
item.media:description: Market stalls in Kingston upon Thames, England. Britons who had already stared down a year of economic and political turmoil met the latest developments with anxiety and concern.

item.title: Conservatives Scramble to Replace Liz Truss as U.K. Leader
item.description: Ms. Truss announced her resignation after six weeks in office, as virtually all her signature tax cuts were being reversed, a stark repudiation of her leadership.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Liz Truss announced her intention to resign as Britain’s prime minister outside 10 Downing Street in London on Thursday.

item.title: Thousands Relocated From Kherson as Ukrainians Close In
item.description: Moscow-backed authorities forecast moving up to 60,000 civilians from the occupied southern region, which analysts say could be a prelude to Russia’s military withdrawal from the city of Kherson.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Only a few people remained in the village of Kamyanka on Wednesday.

item.title: Many Russian Men Flee Moscow in Fear of Draft
item.description: Across the capital, there are noticeably fewer men at restaurants, stores and social gatherings. Many have been called up to fight in Ukraine. Others have fled to avoid being drafted.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

item.title: Preserving a Palestinian Identity in the Kitchen
item.description: With many Palestinians fearful that their cuisine is being lost, kitchen practices handed down by family matriarchs for generations are still being passed along.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariam Sindawi in the kitchen of her home, in Haifa, Israel, with her granddaughter Abeer Abbasi. “Our relationship is really based around the kitchen,” Ms. Abbasi said.

item.title: In Britain, Demands for Tough Response After Beating at Chinese Consulate
item.description: Activists who fled Hong Kong and some British lawmakers have called for a tough government response to the episode in Manchester, as the man who was beaten spoke out.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Ben Stansall/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Bob Chan, a Hong Kong pro-democracy protester, was kicked and beaten just inside the gates of the Chinese Consulate in Manchester, England, on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Errors Prompted Deployment of Iranian Drone Personnel to Ukraine, US Confirms
item.description: John Kirby, a National Security Council official, also warned that Russia may try to buy advanced missiles from Iran.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and John Ismay
item.media:credit: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A drone believed to be an Iranian Shahed-136, which explodes on impact, nearing a target in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Liz Truss Quits
item.description: Plus accounts of torture in Ukraine and Taiwan’s ambitious diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Alberto Pezzali/Associated Press
item.media:description: Britain’s Prime Minister Liz Truss addresses the media in Downing Street in London.

item.title: As War Rages, a Ukrainian Family in Michigan Holds On to Home
item.description: Amber Galkin and her children find themselves navigating complicated connections with their homeland as they embrace a new national identity.
item.dc:creator: Peter Kujawinski and Erin Kirkland for The New York Times

item.title: For King Charles, Liz Truss’s Resignation Presents an Early Test
item.description: King Charles has never sworn in a prime minister, and he will not be crowned until May, making the task of projecting stability more difficult.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yui Mok
item.media:description: King Charles III meeting with Prime Minister Liz Truss at Buckingham Palace in London in September, shortly after the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Memes Accompanied Liz Truss’s Rise, And Helped Propel Her Fall.
item.description: One of Ms. Truss’s defining talents as a politician has been her willingness to embrace a provocative message — and to provide visuals to match.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss onstage at the Conservative Party’s annual conference in Birmingham, England, this month.

item.title: American Woman Pleads Guilty in Death of British Teenager
item.description: Anne Sacoolas pleaded guilty on Thursday to causing the death of Harry Dunn, a 19-year-old British motorcyclist, in 2019, when she was a State Department employee in England.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Alastair Grant/Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of Harry Dunn’s family arriving for a court hearing in London on Thursday. An American, Anne Sacoolas, pleaded guilty to causing Mr. Dunn’s death.

item.title: Virginia Uses Treated Wastewater to Shore Up a Drinking Water Aquifer
item.description: A crucial aquifer is running low, so officials are pumping in treated sewage. It’s an increasingly common strategy as heavy demand and climate change strain water supplies.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Kristen Zeis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sediment sample taken this week in Newport News, Va. A planned recharge well at the site will inject additional treated wastewater into the Potomac Aquifer.

item.title: Biden Says US-UK Partnership Is Strong After Liz Truss Resignation
item.description: “She was a great partner on Russia and Ukraine,” President Biden said of the British leader. “And the British are going to solve their problem.”
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Liz Truss and President Biden met at the United Nations building in New York in September.

item.title: Boris Johnson Expected to Be a Candidate in Conservative Leadership Race
item.description: When the former prime minister left in September, he hinted at a potential comeback. He is now being mentioned as a successor to Liz Truss.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Aaron Chown/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: During his final speech as prime minister on Sept. 6, Boris Johnson hinted at the possibility of a comeback.

item.title: EU Places New Sanctions on Iran for Supplying Russia With Drones
item.description: The sanctions will target the company that manufactures Shahed-136 drones, diplomats said, as well as three individuals.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered outside Iran’s Embassy in Kyiv after Russia used Iranian-supplied explosive drones to attack the city center on Monday.

item.title: Read Liz Truss’s Resignation Speech
item.description: “I cannot deliver the mandate on which I was elected by the Conservative Party,” she said in a televised statement on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Liz Truss resigned as the prime minister of Britain in a televised statement on Thursday.

item.title: What Happened With Liz Truss in Britain? A Guide to the Basics.
item.description: A little over six weeks into her leadership, the British prime minister said she would resign.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Alberto Pezzali/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain announced on Thursday that she would resign, as her husband, Hugh O’Leary, looked on.

item.title: Shetland Is Cut Off From the World After Undersea Cable Breaks
item.description: The remote archipelago became even more so with phone and internet service disrupted. Scotland’s police were patrolling the region and urging residents to avoid non-urgent calls.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lerwick, in the Shetland Islands. There are about 100 islands in Shetland, only 16 of which are inhabited.

item.title: These Are the Likely Front-Runners to Replace Liz Truss
item.description: Penny Mordaunt, Rishi Sunak and Ben Wallace, all current or former Conservative cabinet members, are seen as candidates for Britain’s next prime minister.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Susannah Ireland/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, Britain’s former chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: 1897: India Frontier Fighting
item.description: A skirmish between British-led colonial forces and Pashtuns in what would later become northwestern Pakistan, near Afghanistan, left 10 dead and 53 wounded.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: The State of the Midterms
item.description: The midterm elections are less than three weeks away. We explain the state of the races for the House and Senate.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times

item.title: Nyege Nyege, a Cutting-Edge Music Festival in Uganda, Keeps the Beat
item.description: Despite being called “immoral” by some politicians, this year’s Nyege Nyege festival celebrated diversity and innovation in contemporary African music.
item.dc:creator: Tom Faber
item.media:credit: Martin Kharumwa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: DJ Kampire of Uganda is one of the Nyege Nyege collective’s biggest stars.

item.title: U.S. Sees Opportunity for Ukraine to Capitalize on Russian Weakness
item.description: The next six weeks, before fall mud spreads, could allow Ukraine’s military to press forward in the Donbas and potentially retake Kherson, American officials said. But Russia may not be deterred.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military analysts say that Ukrainian forces have momentum on their side.

item.title: ‘Modern Love’ Goes Global in New Television Series
item.description: The latest iteration of the “Modern Love” franchise, “Modern Love Tokyo,” begins streaming on Oct. 21.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: The Iranian Drones in Ukraine’s Already Crowded Skies
item.description: Russian forces have deployed two types of Iranian drones. Dozens of models of the remote-controlled and programmable weapons are now being used in the war.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the site of an explosive drone strike in Kyiv on Monday, when Iranian Shahed-136 drones struck the city.

item.title: Putin Declares Martial Law in 4 Illegally Annexed Ukrainian Regions
item.description: The Russian leader also imposed restrictions in over two dozen areas in Russia, signaling an attempt to crack down on dissent at home.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed vehicles on Wednesday in Bakhmut, in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region, which has been under constant assault by Russian forces.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Declares Martial Law In Occupied Ukraine
item.description: Plus the British prime minister pushed to resign, China’s most powerful female politician to retire.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hard
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: Carrying Ukrainian flags in a city administration building that was heavily damaged by shelling in the Donetsk region of Ukraine this week.

item.title: Biden Expands Effort to Lower Gas Prices and Secure Energy Independence
item.description: Depleting emergency oil reserves spurs criticism that the White House is trying to lower gas prices with midterm election politics in mind.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said that he has ordered the release of 15 million additional barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to address gas shortage concerns.

item.title: Schoolgirl’s Killing Shocks France and Fuels Right-Wing Fury
item.description: An Algerian woman who had been ordered to leave the country has been arrested and charged in the killing of a girl who was found in a box in Paris, stoking anger over the government’s immigration record.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Geoffroy Van Der Hasselt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Bouquets at the entrance of the building where the 12-year-old girl, Lola, lived in Paris.

item.title: E.V. Bonanza Flows to Red States That Denounce Biden Climate Policies
item.description: No Republican in Congress voted for the Inflation Reduction Act. But their districts and states will greatly benefit from the investments spurred by the law.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Juan Diego Reyes for The New York Times
item.media:description: BMW said on Wednesday that it would expand its manufacturing complex in Spartanburg, S.C.

item.title: Russia Shrinks Forces in Syria, a Factor in Israeli Strategy There
item.description: Moscow withdrew a key air defense system and some troops to bolster its war in Ukraine, officials said, potentially altering Israel’s calculations about striking Syria or arming Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Delil Souleiman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Russian military police in the northeastern Syrian city of Qamishli in 2020. Moscow is sending more military police to Syria to help replace troops withdrawn from the country.

item.title: Iran Denies It Supplied Russia With Drones
item.description: Iran has denied supplying Russia with drones for use in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ed Ram/Getty Images
item.media:description: An apartment building in Kyiv was among many sites of drone strikes across Ukraine this week. The European Union is preparing to impose sanctions on the Iranian company that manufactures drones that Russia is using.

item.title: The Lettuce Outlasts Liz Truss
item.description: Inspired by a columnist’s turn of phrase, a British newspaper tracked whether the embattled prime minister could survive longer than off-the-shelf produce.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: The Daily Star
item.media:description: A days-old head of lettuce has become a caricature of Prime Minister Liz Truss’s tenuous grip on power in Britain.

item.title: Liz Truss Fires Home Secretary Suella Braverman After Email Breach
item.description: Britain’s prime minister dismissed Suella Braverman after an email breach. Ms. Truss was also grilled in Parliament over her repudiated budget.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Rob Pinney/Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain said she would guarantee a pension increase that her finance chief had called into question.

item.title: Iranian Climber Elnaz Rekabi Is Welcomed by Crowds in Tehran
item.description: Elnaz Rekabi, whose appearance without a head scarf at an event in Seoul raised fears about her future, was welcomed home by crowds in Tehran. Her motivations, and her fate, however, remain unclear.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Rhea Kang/International Federation of Sport Climbing, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Elnaz Rekabi competing at the Asian Championships in Seoul on Sunday, in a photograph provided by the International Federation of Sport Climbing.

item.title: The Two Inflation Crises
item.description: Why Europe’s inflation crisis is different from America’s.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oxford Circus in London this year.

item.title: India Bars Kashmiri Photographer From Traveling to Receive Pulitzer
item.description: The Indian authorities stopped Sanna Irshad Mattoo at the New Delhi airport, in the latest case of harassment of journalists in the country.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Saqib Majeed/SOPA Images/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Kashmiri photojournalist Sanna Irshad Mattoo, center, celebrating her Pulitzer Prize for feature photography at her home in Srinagar in May.

item.title: South Korean Super App Kakao Goes Down, Putting a Halt on Life
item.description: A days-long outage at Kakao has led to the resignation of a co-CEO and a reckoning over Big Tech’s extensive grip over the South Korean economy.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Hwang Gwang-Mo/Yonhap, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The co-chiefs of Kakao. Namkoong Whon, left, and Hong Eun-taek, right, during a news conference at Kakao’s office in Pangyo, South Korea, on Wednesday.

item.title: Waiting for Refugee Status, Thousands Live in Limbo
item.description: As the Biden administration prioritizes resettling people fleeing Ukraine and Afghanistan, many other refugees are waiting years in a system struggling to rebuild.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Feroza Binti Abdul Rashid, a Rohingya refugee, and her 5-year-old daughter at their home in Milwaukee. Her husband has not been able to join the family in the United States.

item.title: Britain Slashes Foreign Aid: ‘You Couldn’t Pick a Worse Time’
item.description: The nation is often the second-largest donor to groups working in poor countries to prevent and treat infectious diseases, and to provide reproductive health services to women.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A shipment of medical supplies, sent from the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office in Britain, arriving in New Delhi last year.

item.title: South Korea Gets Squeezed Between the US and China
item.description: The intensifying rivalry between Washington and Beijing is causing jitters in South Korea, where security ties and economic priorities are not always aligned.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents and protesters blocked a road to the nearby Thaad base in Soseong-ri, South Korea, in September.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russian attacks on Ukrainian power stations.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: An 87-year-old woman wept on Tuesday as she recalled surviving a Russian missile strike on the house next door in Kupiansk last week. Her home was heavily damaged.

item.title: Russia Targets Power, Water and Heat for Ukraine’s Civilians
item.description: The stepped-up attacks on cities, including through the heavy use of Iranian-made exploding drones, threaten a new sort of humanitarian crisis for Ukrainians this winter.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Monday combed though the rubble of a building in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was hit by an exploding drone.

item.title: Brittney Griner Releases Message on Her Birthday to Thank Her Supporters
item.description: The basketball star’s lawyers said they had met with her for several hours on Tuesday and relayed messages from well-wishers.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Downes, Valerie Hopkins, Michael Crowley and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, who has been detained in Russia since February, in Khimki, Russia, in August.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Airstrikes Cripple Ukraine’s Power Stations
item.description: Plus what’s at stake in the U.S. midterms and what China’s delay in releasing economic data means
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hard and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Clodagh Kilcoyne/Reuters
item.media:description: People shopping in a supermarket as Kharkiv suffers an electricity outage in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Iran Sends Drone Trainers to Crimea to Aid Russian Military
item.description: The trainers from Iran’s paramilitary wing have been deployed to help Russia overcome mechanical problems with the fleet.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest outside the Iranian Embassy in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Russian officials hint that their hold on Kherson is shaky.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian military vehicle near Mykolaivka in Ukraine’s Kherson region this month.
